meta.title: Cellulitis and skin abscess (skin and soft tissue infections)

content:
Introduction

Cellulitis and skin abscesses are skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) typically caused by bacteria.  Cellulitis involves infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat, whereas skin abscesses are encapsulated pus collections that typically develop due to bacterial invasion through hair follicles (furuncles) or breaks in the skin.  Both conditions can generally be treated effectively (eg, antibiotics, incision and drainage), but early diagnosis and intervention are crucial to preventing complications.

Microbiology



SSTIs are typically divided into 2 types (

):

Nonpurulent cellulitis



Nonpurulent cellulitis is characterized by skin warmth, edema, and erythema with no fluctuant nodules.  It is most often caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci (groups A, B, C, G, and F); group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) accounts for the majority of cases.

Purulent SSTI



Purulent SSTI is characterized by a painful, fluctuant nodule in the dermis or subcutaneous tissue with or without surrounding erythema.  This includes skin abscesses, furuncles (deep infections near hair follicles), and carbuncles (confluences of furuncles).  The most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus, which includes both methicillin-susceptible (MSSA) and methicillin-resistant (MRSA) strains.  Strains that express the virulence factor Panton-Valentine leukocidin are particularly likely to cause skin abscesses.



MRSA should be suspected in patients with:



  • Recent hospitalization or surgery
  • History of MRSA infection
  • Injection drug use
  • Immunosuppression (eg, neutropenia)
  • Extensive burns
  • Evidence of systemic toxicity (eg, fever, hypotension)


Skin abscesses affecting the perioral, perirectal, or vulvovaginal areas often involve polymicrobial infections, including pathogens such as S aureus, S pyogenes, gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes, distinguishing them from typical skin abscesses caused by single pathogens.

Pathophysiology



Cellulitis arises from bacterial invasion into the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, often through a break in the skin barrier.  Common routes of entry include:



  • Minor skin trauma (eg, abrasions, insect bites)
  • Chronic skin conditions (eg, eczema, ulcers)
  • Surgical wounds


Following bacterial invasion, the host immune system mounts an inflammatory response characterized by vasodilation, edema, and infiltration of neutrophils and lymphocytes.  These processes contribute to the cardinal signs and symptoms of cellulitis: erythema, warmth, swelling, and pain.



Similar to cellulitis, skin abscesses arise from bacterial invasion through a break in the skin.  However, in an abscess, the body attempts to wall off the infection by creating a localized collection of pus, which consists of dead white blood cells, bacteria, and tissue debris.  This localized pocket prevents the infection from spreading farther but typically requires drainage to resolve completely.

Risk factors



Most cases of cellulitis are driven by disruptions to the skin barrier due to minor trauma, lymphedema, or dermatophytic (eg, tinea pedis) infection, all of which provide a portal of entry for bacteria.  Immunosuppression (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV), skin barrier disruption (eg, dry skin, chronic inflammation), and chronic edema (eg, chronic venous insufficiency, lymphedema) are all risk factors (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Risk for abscess is increased in those with skin inflammation (eg, atopic dermatitis), trauma, or edema (due to impaired lymphatic drainage or venous insufficiency).

Clinical presentation



The classic presentation of cellulitis is typically unilateral and includes:



  • Erythema:  redness of the skin, often described as spreading and poorly demarcated
  • Warmth:  affected area that feels warm to the touch compared to surrounding skin
  • Swelling:  edema due to fluid accumulation within the tissues
  • Pain:  involved area that may be tender or painful to touch


The course tends to be gradual and indolent.  In some cases, fever (typically, later in the course), malaise, and nausea may occur; regional lymphangitis/lymphadenitis may be present.



A skin abscess often presents as a localized, red, tender, and swollen area with a central point (fluctuance) that may be pus-filled.  Surrounding skin may be red and inflamed; regional lymphadenopathy may be present.  Systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise can occur with larger abscesses.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on the characteristic presentation.  However, in some cases (eg, signs of systemic toxicity, immunosuppression), other studies may be helpful.  Laboratory studies often show leukocytosis with a predominance of neutrophils, a characteristic of most acute bacterial infections.  Blood cultures (positive in <10% of cases) may be useful in identifying the pathogen.  In systemically ill patients, obtaining markers of inflammation (eg, C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and sepsis (eg, lactic acid level) may be warranted.



Imaging studies are not routinely used in diagnosing uncomplicated cellulitis or simple abscesses but may be helpful in more complicated cases:



  • Ultrasonography:  can be used to differentiate cellulitis from a deep abscess or deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
  • CT/MRI:  may be used in rare cases to assess for deeper soft tissue involvement, particularly if there is concern for necrotizing fasciitis (although management should not be delayed for imaging)

Management



The mainstay of treatment for cellulitis is antibiotics.  The choice of antibiotic depends on the suspected causative organism and local resistance patterns.

Nonpurulent cellulitis



Many cases of nonpurulent cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics.  For typical cases involving streptococci or MSSA, first-line therapy (

figure 1
) options include:



  • Dicloxacillin
  • Cephalexin


For cases at high risk of MRSA, first-line therapy options (which target both Streptococcus and MRSA) include:



  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
  • Amoxicillin plus doxycycline


In contrast, parenteral antibiotics should be considered for those with systemic signs of infection, rapidly progressive symptoms, persistent symptoms after 48 hours of oral antibiotics, or an inability to tolerate oral therapy.  Possible parental antibiotic options in immunocompetent adults due to streptococci or MSSA and no evidence of sepsis include:



  • Cefazolin
  • Nafcillin
  • Vancomycin (if MRSA is suspected or if there is a beta-lactam allergy)


Immunocompromised patients or those with more severe infections (eg, sepsis) should receive cefepime in addition to vancomycin.



Patients can transition to oral therapy once there is clinical improvement and no evidence of sepsis.  Treatment duration typically ranges from 5-10 days.

Abscess



The majority of abscesses should be treated with incision and drainage.  Occasionally, small, self-draining abscesses may resolve without incision and drainage.  Routine cultures of debrided material are not necessary in simple abscesses but may be indicated in patients with severe infections; recurrent, resistant, or multiple abscesses; and high-risk comorbid conditions (lymphedema, malignancy, neutropenia).



Empiric antibiotics are typically unnecessary in healthy patients with small abscesses and no surrounding cellulitis but should be considered for patients with abscesses â‰¥2 cm, extensive surrounding cellulitis, systemic signs of infection, neutropenia, or multiple abscesses.  Empiric therapy for abscesses should cover MRSA.  Oral options include:



  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
  • Doxycycline or minocycline


Similar to cellulitis, parenteral antibiotics (eg, vancomycin plus cefepime) should be considered for those with more severe infections.

Special epidemiologic circumstances



Antibiotic selection may need adjustment in specific circumstances that may involve uncommon organisms such as infection that follows a mammalian bite, is caused by water or soil, and occurs in immunocompromised patients (eg, neutropenia), as summarized in the table (

).

Adjunctive measures



  • Elevation:  Elevating the affected limb can help reduce swelling (swelling can impair antibiotic penetration).
  • Warm compresses:  Application to the affected area can improve comfort and blood flow.
  • Compression therapy:  indicated as a preventative measure in patients with recurrent cellulitis of the lower extremities in the setting of chronic lower extremity venous insufficiency or lymphedema.

Complications



While most cases of cellulitis respond well to antibiotics and abscesses typically resolve with incision and drainage, there can be potential complications if left untreated or if the infection spreads to deeper tissues.



  • Bacteremia/sepsis:  Spread of the infection to the bloodstream can lead to bacteremia and sepsis (with the potential for infective endocarditis).
  • Lymphangitis:  Inflammation of the lymphatic vessels can occur with cellulitis, which can lead to swelling, warmth, and pain along the affected vessel (which may appear as red streaking), as well as bacteremia and sepsis.
  • Septic thrombophlebitis:  Inflammation of a vein caused by an adjacent bacterial infection can lead to clot formation within the vein, causing localized pain, swelling, and redness.  Moreover, septic emboli resulting from this condition can lead to various complications such as osteomyelitis, septic joint, and septic pulmonary embolism.
  • Osteomyelitis/septic arthritis:  Bone and joint infections can occur when bacterial infections spread and involve these structures, leading to substantial morbidity.  Complications may include long-term disability or systemic spread of infection if not promptly treated.

Prognosis



The prognosis for cellulitis and abscesses is generally good with prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment.  Most uncomplicated infections resolve within a week with antibiotics.  Early recognition and intervention are crucial to preventing complications.

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) can mimic cellulitis and require careful differentiation to ensure appropriate management.

Other SSTIs



  • Erysipelas:  is a superficial skin and soft tissue infection (
    figure 2
    ), similar in etiology (generally streptococci) and clinical presentation to cellulitis.  However, erysipelas is limited to the epidermis and superficial dermis (cellulitis involves deeper soft tissues), which gives erysipelas its characteristic well-demarcated (
    figure 3
    ), raised (vs flat) borders and intense erythema.  Fever can develop early in the course, but systemic manifestations are otherwise less likely.
  • Impetigo:  is a highly contagious superficial skin infection (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ) caused by staphylococci or streptococci that is most common in young children.  Nonbullous impetigo (
    image 1
    ) is characterized by erythematous pustules that subsequently develop a classic thick, honey-colored crusting.  In bullous impetigo (typically from an exfoliative toxin), vesicles and blisters form with a positive Nikolsky sign.  The face, arms, and legs are most commonly infected.
  • Venous stasis dermatitis:  is a chronic condition (
    image 2
    ) can sometimes mimic cellulitis, particularly when presenting with lower leg swelling and redness.  However, unlike cellulitis, it typically develops gradually, is often bilateral, and has a more chronic course.  It may also present with additional features such as pigmentation changes, eczema-like scaling, and ulceration in the affected area.
  • Necrotizing fasciitis:  is a rapidly progressive and life-threatening infection that in its early stages may appear similar to cellulitis but involves structures deep to the skin (eg, fascia) and requires emergency surgical debridement in addition to intravenous antibiotics.


Other infectious etiologies (eg, gas gangrene, toxic shock syndrome, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome) can be considered based on the clinical presentation.

Nondermatologic conditions



  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT):  can cause swelling, erythema, and pain but is more likely associated with risk factors for blood clots such as recent surgery, prolonged immobilization, or chronic venous insufficiency.  DVT pain is often described as a dull ache or cramping sensation, whereas cellulitis pain is typically sharp and throbbing.  Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) are not typically present.  Ultrasonography is diagnostic.
  • Gout:  typically presents with sudden-onset severe redness, swelling, and exquisite tenderness in a joint, most commonly the first metatarsophalangeal joint.  It is less commonly associated with fever or systemic symptoms.  Examination of synovial fluid can definitively differentiate it from cellulitis.
  • Vasculitis:  is caused by inflammation of blood vessels that can sometimes cause skin lesions that mimic cellulitis.  However, it typically causes additional symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and organ dysfunction due to impaired blood flow.


In addition, insect bites, allergic reactions (medications, vaccine site reactions), and contact dermatitis can mimic cellulitis.

Summary



Nonpurulent cellulitis and skin abscesses are both commonly caused by bacterial infections, although they differ in presentation and management.  Nonpurulent cellulitis is an acute, diffuse infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, most commonly caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci.  It presents with redness, swelling, warmth, and pain in the affected area and is usually treated with oral antibiotics.  Abscesses are localized collections of pus resulting from bacterial infections, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus.  They appear as painful, swollen, and fluctuating masses and can be accompanied by systemic symptoms.  Treatment generally involves incision and drainage, with antibiotic therapy added based on factors such as abscess size, location, and the patient's overall health.  Accurate diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for effective treatment and prevention of complications.
